column2: ENGLISH
The Giants Causeway
Ancient meeting place of the giant Fomorians, this place has kept a great importance for the sons of Mil.
The Lia Fàil
Sacred stone of Kings sitting on top of the hill of Tara, at the touch of the rightful king of Ireland, it screams his name three times.
The Stones of Carnac
Whether the remnants of a Roman army turned to stone by Merlin or ancient temple grounds of their primeval ancestors, the stones of Carnac are considered a sacred destination by many Celts.
Stonehenge
An important pilgrimage site, this stone circle, standing from times immemorial, is often used by the Druids for their sacred ceremonies.
The Hill of Uisneach
Known as the sacred centre of Ireland, this hill is also the chosen site for the annual celebration of Beltaine.
The Ring of Brodgar
Most important stone circle in in northern Scotland, the Druids have made this a sacred temple to the Gods
Sacred Bears
The Bear is highly sacred in this region, thought to be the earthly avatar of many powerful gods and goddesses.
Sacred Horses
Protected by Macha, the white horses are a sign of the favour she has for this region.
Sacred Yew Trees
A symbol of immortality, the mighty yew trees that grow in the sacred groves are a gift from the Gods.
Sacred Stags
Companion to the Gods and the many spirits of the land, the stags and deer of this area are particularly healthy.
Sacred Dogs
Dogs were seen to be keen-scented, good at hunting, guarding and healing themselves, their abundance in this region is clearly a gift.
Sacred Oaks
The great Oaks and the sacred mistletoe that they bear are of utmost importance to the Celts.
Standing Stones
Often the site of pilgrimages, standing stones are a boon for any lord, their presence lending prestige and protection.
Sacred Lake
This mysterious lake is often the recipient of gifts to the Gods, for its waters are considered a pathway to the Otherworld.
Sacred Spring
The waters flowing from this source are thought to hold healing powers and are thus sacred.
Sacred River
A goddess is believed to reside in the waters of this river, blessing all peoples living near it.

The spirits and minor gods of the land must also be appeased.

Restless Sidhe
The Sidhe in this province are restless and are the cause of many troubles.

This character is thought to be a changeling, switched at birth by fairies
The gods are unsatisfied with our rule.\n
The Cauldron of Dyrnwch the Giant
If meat for a coward were put in it to boil, it would never boil, but if meat for a brave man were put in it, it would boil quickly.
The Chariot of Morgan Mwynfawr
If a man went in it, he might wish to be wherever he would, and he would be there quickly.
The Chessboard of Gwenddoleu ap Ceidio
If the pieces were set, they would play by themselves. The board was of gold, and the men of silver.
The Coat of Padarn Beisrudd
If a well-born man put it on, it would be the right size for him, if a churl, it would not go upon him.
The Crock and Dish of Rhygenydd Ysgolhaig
Whatever food might be wished for in them, it would be found.
Dyrnwyn, the Sword of Rhydderch Hael

If any man drew it except himself, it burst into a flame from the cross to the point, and all who asked it received it, but because of this property all shunned it, and therefore was he called Rhydderch Hael.
The Halter of Clydno Eiddyn
Which was fixed to a staple at the foot of his bed: whatever horse he might wish for, he would find in the halter.
The Hamper of Gwyddno Garanhir
Food for one man would be put in it, and when it was opened, food for a hundred men would be found in it.
The Horn of Brân Galed
Whatever drink might be wished for was found in it
The Knife of Llawfrodedd the Horseman
Which would serve for twenty-four men to eat at table.
The Mantle of Arthur
Whoever was under it could not be seen, and he could see everyone.
The Mantle of Tegau Gold-Breast
For all unchaste women the mantle will not cover them, nor will it maintain a single colour.
The Stone and Ring of Eluned the Fortunate
If her lover wore the ring's stone within his hand and closed his fist about the stone he would be concealed.
The Whetstone of Tudwal Tudglyd

If a brave man sharpened his sword on the whetstone, then the sword would certainly kill any man from whom it drew blood. If a cowardly man used the whetstone, though, his sword would refuse to draw blood at all.
